articles.headline: Growing Concern About Tainted Eggs After Recall
articles.snippet: Hillandale Farms issued a recall of eggs it sent to 14 states that were linked to a recent salmonella outbreak.
articles.abstract: Hillandale Farms issued a recall of eggs it sent to 14 states that were linked to a recent salmonella outbreak.
articles.lead_paragraph: A national outbreak of salmonella was linked on Friday to another major egg producer, Hillandale Farms, prompting the recall of an additional 170 million eggs in 14 states.

articles.headline: How to Be Frugal and Still Be Asked on Dates
articles.snippet: There are ways to broadcast your financial values without coming off as a tightwad or a gold digger.
articles.abstract: There are ways to broadcast your financial values without coming off as a tightwad or a gold digger.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saving may be making a comeback, but it still hasn’t gotten its sexy back, particularly if you’re a man.

articles.headline: Nespresso and Rivals Vie for Dominance in Coffee War
articles.snippet: Competitors say Nestlé is trying to lock them out of the lucrative market for coffee in single-use pods.
articles.abstract: Competitors say Nestlé is trying to lock them out of the lucrative market for coffee in single-use pods.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — George Clooney and John Malkovich aren’t the only coffee lovers fighting over a Nespresso these days.

articles.headline: Facebook Feels Unfriendly Toward Film It Inspired
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg, the company founder, has been locked in a standoff with the makers of a film about the social network.
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, the company founder, has been locked in a standoff with the makers of a film about the social network.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  At the New York Film Festival next month, Hollywood will unleash “The Social Network,” a biting tale of the Silicon Valley giant Facebook and its founder Mark Zuckerberg.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: In Mideast Talks, Scant Hopes From the Beginning
articles.snippet: There is little confidence that the Obama administration’s goal of reaching a Mideast peace deal in one year can be met.
articles.abstract: There is little confidence that the Obama administration’s goal of reaching a Mideast peace deal in one year can be met.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  The American invitation on Friday to the Israelis and Palestinians to start direct peace talks in two weeks in Washington was immediately accepted by both governments. But just below the surface there was an almost audible shrug. There is little confidence  close to none  on either side that the Obama administration’s goal of reaching a comprehensive deal in one year can be met.

articles.headline: Pension Fraud in New Jersey Puts Focus on Illinois
articles.snippet: Cities and states are scrambling to make sure their pension disclosures are in order, and investors in distressed debt are scrambling, sensing opportunity.
articles.abstract: Cities and states are scrambling to make sure their pension disclosures are in order, and investors in distressed debt are scrambling, sensing opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government’s crackdown on the State of New Jersey this week for misrepresenting the condition of its pension funds raises a question: Who else might have pension numbers that could draw regulatory fire?

articles.headline: Details Faulted in Plan to Pay Oil Spill Claims
articles.snippet: The details of exactly how the $20 billion fund set up by BP will be distributed drew sharp criticism from several quarters.
articles.abstract: The details of exactly how the $20 billion fund set up by BP will be distributed drew sharp criticism from several quarters.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  The details of exactly how the $20 billion fund set up by BP will be distributed to those affected by the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, which were made public on Friday, did little to allay worries and suspicions here, drawing instead sharp criticism from several quarters.

articles.headline: Consumers Clamoring for a Leader
articles.snippet: A groundswell of support is rising for Elizabeth Warren, who proposed the newly created financial reform agency in 2007, to be named to lead it.
articles.abstract: A groundswell of support is rising for Elizabeth Warren, who proposed the newly created financial reform agency in 2007, to be named to lead it.
articles.lead_paragraph: So it turns out that the Elizabeth Warren rap video that went “viral” this week is actually a made-in-Hollywood production.

articles.headline: As Mission Shifts in Iraq, Risks Linger for Obama
articles.snippet: The combat mission’s end in Iraq presents risks as President Obama seeks to claim credit without issuing a premature declaration of victory.
articles.abstract: The combat mission’s end in Iraq presents risks as President Obama seeks to claim credit without issuing a premature declaration of victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The official end of America’s combat mission in Iraq next week will fulfill the campaign promise that helped vault President Obama to the White House, but it also presents profound risks as he seeks to claim credit without issuing a premature declaration of victory.

articles.headline: In Case of Emergency: What Not to Do
articles.snippet: P.R. missteps at BP, Toyota and Goldman Sachs raise a question: Are some crises impossible to spin?
articles.abstract: P.R. missteps at BP, Toyota and Goldman Sachs raise a question: Are some crises impossible to spin?
articles.lead_paragraph: WHOEVER suggested that all publicity is good publicity clearly never envisioned the wave of catastrophe engulfing high-profile corporations over the last year, laying waste to some of the most meticulously tailored reputations on earth.

articles.headline: Debt’s Deadly Grip
articles.snippet: In this climate, how can consumers dig their way out of credit problems?
articles.abstract: In this climate, how can consumers dig their way out of credit problems?
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S one of the toughest lessons an investor has to learn: while the value of assets can plummet posthaste, it takes forever to shrink the debt that was used to buy them.

articles.headline: In Striking Shift, Small Investors Flee Stock Market
articles.snippet: With renewed economic uncertainty, American investors have withdrawn a staggering $33.12 billion from stock market mutual funds so far this year.
articles.abstract: With renewed economic uncertainty, American investors have withdrawn a staggering $33.12 billion from stock market mutual funds so far this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Renewed economic uncertainty is testing Americans’ generation-long love affair with the stock market.

articles.headline: Stock Swing Still Baffles, With an Ominous Tone
articles.snippet: Months later, analysts are still seeking the cause of a quick and mysterious plunge of the stock markets; some suspect a conspiracy.
articles.abstract: Months later, analysts are still seeking the cause of a quick and mysterious plunge of the stock markets; some suspect a conspiracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounds like “Wall Street” meets “The X-Files.”

articles.headline: Pakistanis Tell of Motive in Taliban Leader’s Arrest
articles.snippet: Pakistani officials say they set out to capture Abdul Ghani Baradar because they wanted to shut down secret peace talks he had been conducting with the Afghan government.
articles.abstract: Pakistani officials say they set out to capture Abdul Ghani Baradar because they wanted to shut down secret peace talks he had been conducting with the Afghan government.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — When American and Pakistani agents captured Abdul Ghani Baradar, the Taliban’s operational commander, in the chaotic port city of Karachi last January, both countries hailed the arrest as a breakthrough in their often difficult partnership in fighting terrorism.

articles.headline: Housing Fades as a Means to Build Wealth, Analysts Say
articles.snippet: Many economists believe that the days of banking on an asset that could only rise in value are gone for good.
articles.abstract: Many economists believe that the days of banking on an asset that could only rise in value are gone for good.
articles.lead_paragraph: Housing will eventually recover from its great swoon. But many real estate experts now believe that home ownership will never again yield rewards like those enjoyed in the second half of the 20th century, when houses not only provided shelter but also a plump nest egg.

articles.headline: Scrutiny for Chinese Telecom Bid
articles.snippet: Eight Republican lawmakers have asked the Obama administration to study Huawei and its bid to supply equipment to Sprint Nextel.
articles.abstract: Eight Republican lawmakers have asked the Obama administration to study Huawei and its bid to supply equipment to Sprint Nextel.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Warning about a potential threat to national security, eight Republican lawmakers have asked the Obama administration to scrutinize a bid by one of the biggest corporations in China to supply telecommunications equipment to Sprint Nextel in the United States.

articles.headline: In S.E.C. Fraud Suit, Texas Brothers Stand Firm
articles.snippet: Accused of securities fraud in a 78-page complaint, the Wyly brothers say they were victims of bad advice.
articles.abstract: Accused of securities fraud in a 78-page complaint, the Wyly brothers say they were victims of bad advice.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo.  The Texas billionaire Sam Wyly has a laugh that blends the cackle of a mad scientist with the giggle of a teenager  a high-pitched titter that makes him sound thoroughly delighted. Until, that is, talk turns to the recent securities fraud suit against him and his brother, Charles.

articles.headline: Venezuela, More Deadly Than Iraq, Wonders Why
articles.snippet: A debate on the soaring homicide rate was reignited after a court ordered a newspaper to stop publishing violent images.
articles.abstract: A debate on the soaring homicide rate was reignited after a court ordered a newspaper to stop publishing violent images.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  Some here joke that they might be safer if they lived in Baghdad. The numbers bear them out.

articles.headline: In the Living Room, Hooked on Pay TV
articles.snippet: Despite the proliferation of Internet video, few Americans are actually canceling pay TV and watching shows online.
articles.abstract: Despite the proliferation of Internet video, few Americans are actually canceling pay TV and watching shows online.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a fantasy shared by many Americans: dropping cable television and its fat monthly bills and turning instead to the wide-open frontier of Internet video.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Sony’s Bet on Sticking With Web Shows
articles.snippet: Sony Pictures Entertainment has continued to pour money into Crackle.com, looking to ad revenue instead of subscriptions.
articles.abstract: Sony Pictures Entertainment has continued to pour money into Crackle.com, looking to ad revenue instead of subscriptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At first Hollywood raced to make original Web programming. NBC Universal trumpeted a site called DotComedy; the Walt Disney Company created a digital studio called Stage 9; and Time Warner backed SuperDeluxe, another comedy site.

articles.headline: Faith in Its Shows, on Any Medium
articles.snippet: Jeffrey Bewkes of Time Warner isn’t worried about competition. When all videos are on all screens, he expects his company’s brands like HBO, TBS and TNT to stand out.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey Bewkes of Time Warner isn’t worried about competition. When all videos are on all screens, he expects his company’s brands like HBO, TBS and TNT to stand out.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a guy whose world is supposed to be falling apart, Jeffrey Bewkes looks awfully calm.

articles.headline: H.P.’s Bidding War With Dell Underscores the Demand for Data Storage
articles.snippet: Data storage used to be one of the more mundane corners of the technology industry. Now it is where an increasing number of tech companies — and Wall Street — want to be.
articles.abstract: Data storage used to be one of the more mundane corners of the technology industry. Now it is where an increasing number of tech companies — and Wall Street — want to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Data storage used to be one of the more mundane corners of the technology industry. Now it is where an increasing number of tech companies  and Wall Street  want to be.

articles.headline: Graft Dispute in Afghanistan is Test for U.S.
articles.snippet: Afghan officials on Monday sought to shift the blame onto Western critics in an escalating dispute over an arrest.
articles.abstract: Afghan officials on Monday sought to shift the blame onto Western critics in an escalating dispute over an arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  As corruption investigations begin to focus on President Hamid Karzai’s inner circle, an Afghan official on Monday pinned blame for endemic corruption in Afghanistan on foreign contractors, which he said had created an “economic mafia” in the war-torn country.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Scant Progress in Effort on Old Racial Killings
articles.snippet: The Civil Rights-Era Cold Case Initiative has disappointed families of victims, who had hoped for an all-out effort.
articles.abstract: The Civil Rights-Era Cold Case Initiative has disappointed families of victims, who had hoped for an all-out effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  In February 2007, Alberto R. Gonzales, the attorney general under President George W. Bush, issued a stern warning to those who murdered blacks with impunity during the civil rights era: “You have not gotten away with anything. We are still on your trail.”
